author: By Christine Chitnis
title: For Holiday Baking: One Cookie, Three Ways
description: Baking experts show how to transform simple sugar cookies into dazzling treats.
content: It’s time to break out the cookie cutters. Despite a forecast of canceled parties and virtual family gatherings, baking traditions go on. In fact, a scaled-down holiday season offers the perfect opportunity to try your hand at new decorating techniques.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Rick Rojas
title: In Georgia Debate, Kelly Loeffler Won’t Say Trump Lost
description: Republicans fear that President Trump’s grievances about the results might persuade his supporters to sit out Georgia’s two runoff elections, including Ms. Loeffler’s race, that will determine control of the Senate.
content: ATLANTA — In a televised debate on Sunday night, Senator Kelly Loeffler, a Georgia Republican, declined to say that President Trump had lost the election, arguing instead that the president had “every legal recourse available” to pursue his baseless assertion that the vote in Georgia was rigged against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner, Michael S. Schmidt and Peter Baker
title: Barr Is Said to Be Weighing Whether to Leave Before Trump’s Term Ends
description: The attorney general’s future came into doubt after he acknowledged that the Justice Department had not found evidence of widespread voter fraud in the president’s election loss.
content: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr is considering stepping down before President Trump’s term ends next month, according to three people familiar with his thinking. One said Mr. Barr could announce his departure before the end of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin, Astead W. Herndon and Hailey Fuchs
title: Trump called Georgia’s governor to urge him to help overturn Biden’s win in the state.
description: VALDOSTA, Ga. — Before President Trump arrived on Saturday to rally for two Republican Senate candidates, the president made no attempt to disguise his central priority as it relates to Georgia: overturning his loss in the state. He began the day with a telephone call with Gov. Brian Kemp, ostensibly to offer his condolences about the death in a car accident of a young man who was close to Mr. Kemp’s family.
content: VALDOSTA, Ga. — Before President Trump arrived on Saturday to rally for two Republican Senate candidates, the president made no attempt to disguise his central priority as it relates to Georgia: overturning his loss in the state. He began the day with a telephone call with Gov. Brian Kemp, ostensibly to offer his condolences about the death in a car accident of a young man who was close to Mr. Kemp’s family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Roald Dahl’s Family Apologizes for His Anti-Semitism
description: The author, who died in 1990, made several disparaging comments about Jews during his lifetime. “Those prejudiced remarks are incomprehensible to us,” the family said in a statement online.
content: LONDON — The family of Roald Dahl has apologized for “the lasting and understanding hurt” caused by anti-Semitic comments the author made during his lifetime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis, Richard C. Paddock, Dera Menra Sijabat and Isabella Kwai
title: Greek Orthodox Church faces criticism, and other news around the world.
description: The coronavirus has dealt a double blow to the powerful Greek Orthodox Church, with the disease spreading through its ranks even as the clergy fends off criticism that it has been stoking the pandemic.
content: The coronavirus has dealt a double blow to the powerful Greek Orthodox Church, with the disease spreading through its ranks even as the clergy fends off criticism that it has been stoking the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Masha Goncharova
title: Events to Shake, or Gently Rattle, the World in 2021
description: Planning your calendar for next year? Here are a few events to look out for.
content: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year may mean for the year ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: How ‘Wolves’ and ‘Heroes’ Are Saving Pandemic Theater
description: Serious new plays are always in danger of disappearing — never more so than now. But inventive virtual productions, such as “The Wolves” and “Heroes of the Fourth Turning,” offer hope.
content: It’s all well and good that some theaters are making money during the pandemic by producing what can only be called quasi-theater: magic shows, murder mysteries, a hundred variations on “A Christmas Carol.” I won’t congratulate them here; let their income be its own reward. With luck, they may keep the spark of performance alive to light another night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: The Future of Chicken, and More Stimulus Chatter
description: A big step for lab-grown meat. A smaller step toward stimulus talks. And a sprint to stop vaccine misinformation.
content: It’s officially the holiday season, and you’d better get your online shopping done early — the overworked United States Postal Service slapped temporary shipping limits on retailers like Gap and Nike, a sign that delivery systems are bursting at their seams. Here’s what else you need to know about business and tech for the week ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Will Wright
title: ‘Existential Peril’: Mass Transit Faces Huge Service Cuts Across U.S.
description: Reeling from the pandemic, transit agencies are grappling with drastic reductions in ridership and pleading for help from Washington.
content: In Boston, transit officials warned of ending weekend service on the commuter rail and shutting down the city’s ferries. In Washington, weekend and late-night metro service would be eliminated and 19 of the system’s 91 stations would close. In Atlanta, 70 of the city’s 110 bus routes have already been suspended, a move that could become permanent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: Traveling? Be Prepared to Quarantine
description: If you’re thinking of traveling in the coming weeks, here’s what to think about first.
content: Though the number of air travelers topped one million on the Sunday after Thanksgiving, many Americans opted not to travel for the holiday. (The equivalent number a year ago, 2019’s biggest travel day, was more than 2.8 million). But even as coronavirus cases continue to surge, the winter holidays and breaks from school may have more people contemplating taking some time away from home in the coming weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Picks Xavier Becerra to Lead Health and Human Services
description: The selection of Mr. Becerra, the California attorney general, is a surprise. If confirmed, he will face a daunting challenge in leading the department at a critical moment in the pandemic.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has selected Xavier Becerra, the Democratic attorney general of California, as his nominee for secretary of health and human services, tapping a former congressman who would be the first Latino to run the department as it battles the surging coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: Who Wrote ‘Citizen Kane’? It’s No Mystery
description: The Netflix drama “Mank” suggests that Herman J. Mankiewicz, credited along with Orson Welles, primarily wrote the script. But that has long been debunked by scholars.
content: “Mank,” the new drama from David Fincher, revives an old charge against Orson Welles. Was Welles, who with “Citizen Kane” (1941) created what is often cited as the greatest movie ever made on his first try, actually standing on the shoulders of another genius?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: ‘Like a Cattle Yard’: How Justice Is Delivered in Australia’s Bush Courts
description: In some remote Aboriginal communities, judges and lawyers arrive by plane and handle dozens of cases in a single day. Critics say language barriers and the rapid pace infringe on human rights.
content: WADEYE, Australia — After an hourlong flight over the ocher sands of northern Australia, the judge stepped off the plane and made her way to the makeshift courthouse, a single white-walled room next to a new $20 million police station ensconced in barbed wire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Jupiter and Saturn Head for Closest Visible Alignment in 800 Years
description: On Dec. 21, Jupiter and Saturn will appear to be no more than a dime’s width apart in the night sky. The last time that could be seen was in 1226.
content: For months, Saturn and Jupiter have appeared to be courting, as the giant celestial bodies have gradually drawn nearer in the night sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘S.N.L.’ Parodies Rudy Giuliani and Melissa Carone’s Disastrous Hearing
description: Cecily Strong took center stage in a “Saturday Night Live” sketch playing a real-life figure who had already reminded viewers of one of her best-known characters.
content: The emergence of a new public figure in the political sphere is a precious moment for fans of “Saturday Night Live,” one that often sets off a guessing game of which cast member (or, lately, which celebrity guest star) will be playing that person by the weekend. Who would make the best Brett Kavanaugh? The perfect Robert Mueller? The ideal Dr. Anthony Fauci?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: China tries to rewrite the narrative of the pandemic.
content: Facing global anger over their initial mishandling of the coronavirus outbreak, the Chinese authorities are trying to rewrite the narrative of the pandemic by pushing false theories that the virus originated outside China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Beeps and Boops
description: Barb Lin opens our solving week.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Barb Lin starts off our solving week, and her puzzle left me feeling a bit sentimental for trips past. As she mentions in her notes below, I look forward to the day when we can travel safely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: China peddles falsehoods to push the idea that the virus came from somewhere else.
description: Facing global anger over their initial mishandling of the outbreak, the Chinese authorities are now trying to rewrite the narrative of the pandemic by pushing theories that the virus originated outside China.
content: Facing global anger over their initial mishandling of the outbreak, the Chinese authorities are now trying to rewrite the narrative of the pandemic by pushing theories that the virus originated outside China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: After Defying Virus Rules, Bar Manager Drives Car Into Sheriff’s Deputy
description: The manager of Mac’s Public House on Staten Island hit the deputy while fleeing from arrest after authorities confronted him, the sheriff said.
content: The manager of a Staten Island bar who has repeatedly and flamboyantly defied New York’s coronavirus restrictions hit a sheriff’s deputy with his Jeep early Sunday as he unsuccessfully tried to escape arrest, the sheriff’s office said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: China Peddles Falsehoods to Obscure Origin of Covid Pandemic
description: To push the idea that the virus didn’t come from China, the government has misrepresented experts’ remarks and given dubious theories the veneer of science.
content: The mild-mannered German scientist never anticipated becoming a Chinese propaganda star.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Bergamo’s Pandemic Survivors Carry Scars Unseen and Incalculable
description: Plagued by guilt, anger and regrets, those still alive in the hardest hit place in Italy, and perhaps the world, grapple to understand how the virus has changed them.
content: NEMBRO, Italy — Every Monday night in the northern Italian town that had perhaps the highest coronavirus death rate in all of Europe, a psychologist specializing in post-traumatic stress leads group therapy sessions in the local church.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Studying ‘The Nutcracker,’ Students Listen, Touch, Move Like Snow
description: Music students who are blind and visually impaired are offered a five-week course. “For me this class is about being dance,” its teacher says.
content: On a November afternoon, seven young students twirled, hopped and lifted their chests to the sky, as Waltz of the Snowflakes from “The Nutcracker” played through their computer speakers. Gathered for a weekly Zoom class, they had arrived at a part of the lesson that one of their teachers, Jenny Seham, called “freestyle snow dancing”: a moment to channel, through improvised movement, the wonder of Tchaikovsky’s music and the freedom of swirling snow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Giuliani has tested positive for the coronavirus, Trump says.
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York City mayor and President Trump’s personal and campaign lawyer, has tested positive for the coronavirus, Mr. Trump announced on Twitter on Sunday.
content: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York City mayor and President Trump’s personal and campaign lawyer, has tested positive for the coronavirus, Mr. Trump announced on Twitter on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: She Couldn’t Open for Outdoor Dining. The Film Crew Next Door Could.
description: Restaurant owners say Los Angeles County is unfairly enforcing its ban on outdoor dining, but health officials say rules for film crews are much more strict.
content: For more than a week, tensions have flared between Los Angeles restaurant owners and politicians over the county’s ban on outdoor dining, which health officials say is necessary to slow the surging pandemic — and restaurateurs say is destroying their livelihoods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Jets Let Raiders, and a First Win, Slip By
description: The Jets had Sunday’s game firmly in hand with a 4-point lead over Las Vegas and 35 seconds remaining. Then a baffling defensive assignment by the Jets gave the Raiders one last chance to score.
content: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. (AP) — The game appeared all but over and the Raiders were about to lose to the lowly Jets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden has selected Xavier Becerra as his nominee for secretary of health and human services.
description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has selected Xavier Becerra, a former congressman who is now the Democratic attorney general of California, as his nominee for secretary of health and human services, ending a politically delicate search that brought complaints from the Congressional Hispanic Caucus about a lack of Latinos in the incoming cabinet.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has selected Xavier Becerra, a former congressman who is now the Democratic attorney general of California, as his nominee for secretary of health and human services, ending a politically delicate search that brought complaints from the Congressional Hispanic Caucus about a lack of Latinos in the incoming cabinet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: A Polarizing Documentary Spurs Debate Over a Violent Time in Quebec
description: Fifty years after separatist violence prompted the government to send soldiers to Montreal, Quebec is grappling with how to remember the 1970 “October crisis.”
content: MONTREAL— Félix Rose was 7 years old when he realized that the gentle father he idolized had a secret past. “Your daddy killed someone,” his cousin told him during a family celebration, he recalled recently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: As Pandemic Threatens Britain’s Mental Health, These ‘Fishermen’ Fight Back
description: A charity called the Bearded Fishermen has begun a nightly suicide-prevention patrol around a town in England, looking for people in crisis.
content: GAINSBOROUGH, England — The group of seven volunteers in high-visibility vests, equipped with GPS trackers and radios, gathered in the parking lot of a nature preserve on the outskirts of town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales and Natasha Frost
title: Christmas tree sales are booming as pandemic-weary Americans seek solace.
description: Before this year, Wesley Yang had never celebrated with a real Christmas tree. Growing up, his family deemed it an inconvenience. But stuck at home this season, Mr. Yang and his roommate decided to do something different to mark the end of a tragic year, spending $90 on a tree and lugging it up three floors to their Los Angeles apartment.
content: Before this year, Wesley Yang had never celebrated with a real Christmas tree. Growing up, his family deemed it an inconvenience. But stuck at home this season, Mr. Yang and his roommate decided to do something different to mark the end of a tragic year, spending $90 on a tree and lugging it up three floors to their Los Angeles apartment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: After Centuries of Obscurity, Wilmington Is Having a Moment
description: Joe Biden’s hometown, known chiefly for its dull, corporate vibe, has become the center of the political universe. Residents are thrilled.
content: WILMINGTON, Del. — The hometown of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has long wrestled with its image problem. Namely, it does not have one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: What We Learned From Week 13 of the N.F.L. Season
description: The Jets had an epic collapse, the Giants shocked the Seahawks and the Browns clinched their first winning season since 2007.
content: Despite starting a backup quarterback, the Giants stunned the Seahawks in Seattle. The Indianapolis Colts survived a close game against the Houston Texans, the Cleveland Browns hung on for a win over the Tennessee Titans and the New Orleans Saints and the Kansas City Chiefs won yet again. But none of Sunday’s games could match the excitement of a wild matchup between the Las Vegas Raiders and the Jets in which Gang Green managed to snatch defeat from the jaws of victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kit Gillet
title: Romania’s Leader Is Tested by a Close Election
description: Prime Minister Ludovic Orban will need to maintain his alliance with a smaller party to stay in power after a surprisingly tight race.
content: BUCHAREST, Romania — Amid record low turnout, voters in Romania on Sunday dealt a setback to the country’s prime minister, Ludovic Orban, in a surprisingly tight race that threatened his grip on power.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Asked the Driver to Take Me to a Place That Was Seven Blocks Away’
description: A short cab ride, a new place in the West Village and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Dec. 7, 2020
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Frank
title: Rachel Maddow and Michael Yarvitz Tell the Full Sordid Story of Spiro Agnew
description: “Bag Man” reports on who knew what and when about Agnew’s years of corruption.
content: BAG MANThe Wild Crimes, Audacious Cover-Up, and Spectacular Downfall of a Brazen Crook in the White HouseBy Rachel Maddow and Michael Yarvitz
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: In Last-Ditch Bid for Brexit Deal, Leaders’ Theatrics Show the Stakes
description: Boris Johnson and the European Union’s president are preparing their domestic audiences for either a landmark accord requiring compromise or a breakdown that will disrupt cross-channel trade.
content: LONDON — It can be hard, in the climactic days of a high-stakes negotiation, to separate theatrics from substance — and so it was on Saturday evening, when Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain and the president of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, hung up after an hourlong phone call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr
title: Coronavirus Surge, Georgia, Candice Bergen: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: After Perilous Crossing, Migrants Await Fate in Canary Islands Hotels
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, December 6, 2020.
content: “Winter is our main tourism season, and when you come as a tourist, you don’t want to be next to a building that is filled with migrants.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Errol Spence Jr.’s Win Sets Up a Dream Pairing. That’s All It May Be.
description: Spence retained his two world welterweight titles by beating Danny Garcia on Saturday. Does that mean he’ll face Terence Crawford, the W.B.O. champion, next? No, this is boxing.
content: After turning his high-stakes bout with Danny Garcia into a 12-round boxing clinic, Errol Spence Jr., the undefeated welterweight, held a news conference that included reporters gathered at AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas, and others tuning in via Zoom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Pergament
title: How to Help Kids Create an ‘Our Street Herald’
description: Start the presses: Winter at home is a great time for children to publish their own newspaper from the kitchen table.
content: In this era of working from home and schooling from home and exercising from home and making sourdough from home, the question will soon present itself: What else is there to do from home?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: More Than 90,000 Without Power After New England Winter Storm
description: Around 85,000 customers in Maine alone still don’t have electricity after a nor’easter brought high winds and heavy snow.
content: A winter storm that battered parts of New England over the weekend brought high winds and heavy snow that left more than 90,000 utility customers still without power as of Sunday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Cusumano and Emma Grillo
title: Celebrate the Holidays with Cheese Pancakes and a Performance by Taylor Mac
description: This week, learn to fold paper airplanes, watch a new ballet or bake Emily Dickinson a birthday cake.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Find — and Spread — Joy
description: Even during the pandemic.
content: “I made a big batch of chocolate chip cookies for Election Day and delivered them to friends. I so enjoyed seeing my friends and hearing their voices ‘in person’ (socially distanced and masked, of course). Happiness for my friends and also for me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: In Brooklyn Bridge Park, Artwork Confronts Climate Change
description: “Waters of a Lower Register,” by the artist Allison Janae Hamilton, came about when Creative Time had to rethink a year marked by a pandemic, frequent hurricanes and racial injustice.
content: Those who wander the circuitous paths of Pier 3 in Brooklyn Bridge Park may be drawn to the western edge of the pier by the lapping of water. But the sounds may not be coming from the East River, which borders the site.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Do It Yourself Home Repairs
description: With a few tools and a little know-how, these five home repairs are relatively easy to complete.
content: As the pandemic forces us to spend our days hunkered down, our homes face far more strain than usual. Faucets bear the brunt of increased hand-washing, toilets get flushed with greater regularity and appliances experience more frequent use. If you have children at home, it’s also possible that your living room now suffers as much abuse as a gym.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: How Joe Biden’s Digital Team Tamed the MAGA Internet
description: The campaign’s empathetic digital strategy held up surprisingly well against President Trump’s passionate digital following.
content: Last April, when Rob Flaherty, the digital director for Joe Biden’s presidential campaign, told me that the former vice president’s team planned to use feel-good videos and inspirational memes to beat President Trump in a “battle for the soul of the internet,” my first thought was: Good luck with that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Residents of nursing homes could receive vaccine by the end of December, official says.
description: Trump administration officials on Sunday laid out an ambitious timetable for the rollout of the first coronavirus vaccine in the United States, rebuking President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s criticism that there was “no detailed plan that we’ve seen” for getting people immunized.
content: Trump administration officials on Sunday laid out an ambitious timetable for the rollout of the first coronavirus vaccine in the United States, rebuking President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s criticism that there was “no detailed plan that we’ve seen” for getting people immunized.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Geek Out Over Christmas Films
description: Enjoy famous holiday movies communally again at virtual conventions and digital museum exhibits.
content: Theaters would normally be packed this time of year with folks assembled to watch revered holiday films like “It’s a Wonderful Life,” Frank Capra’s 1946 heart-tugger usually returns to big screens over the holidays, including an annual weeks-long run at the IFC Center in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Spend today making Melissa Clark’s desserts and teatime delights for a holiday cookie box.
content: Good morning. We’ll get to dinner soon enough, but I think today might be largely spent making desserts and teatime delights for a holiday cookie box, in keeping with the teachings of Melissa Clark. Make some combination of vanilla bean spritz cookies, cornmeal lime shortbread fans, toasted almond snowballs, black and white brownies and fudgy bourbon balls. You don’t have to eat them all. As Melissa will show you, here’s how to pack them for the mail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Armstrong and Tracey Tully
title: A Covid memorial will rise from a former toxic waste site in New Jersey.
description: Of all the toxic dumps in New Jersey, perhaps none was more infamous than PJP Landfill, which sat at the edge of the Hackensack River in Jersey City and was polluted by hazardous chemicals. For more than a decade there, underground fires erupted spontaneously, belching acrid smoke so thick it could snarl traffic on an adjacent bridge, the Pulaski Skyway, a key link for commuters heading to and from New York City.
content: Of all the toxic dumps in New Jersey, perhaps none was more infamous than PJP Landfill, which sat at the edge of the Hackensack River in Jersey City and was polluted by hazardous chemicals. For more than a decade there, underground fires erupted spontaneously, belching acrid smoke so thick it could snarl traffic on an adjacent bridge, the Pulaski Skyway, a key link for commuters heading to and from New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: New York City prepares to reopen elementary schools amid surge.
description: About 190,000 students in New York City are set to return to classrooms this week, starting with elementary school students on Monday, following a monthslong roller coaster of changes to the most closely watched school reopening effort in the country. Students with complex disabilities will be able to return to school buildings on Wednesday.
content: About 190,000 students in New York City are set to return to classrooms this week, starting with elementary school students on Monday, following a monthslong roller coaster of changes to the most closely watched school reopening effort in the country. Students with complex disabilities will be able to return to school buildings on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodi Levine
title: Top a Present With a Newsprint Bow
description: With some artful folding and a few snips of the scissors, a newspaper can become fanciful gift-toppers (and they’re recyclable).
content: As much as unwrapping a present is part of the delight of receiving a gift, wrapping one can be an enjoyable part of the gift-giving experience. No matter what holiday you are celebrating, these handmade gift-topper ideas — from a fancy bow to a quick-snipped holly leaf — are relaxing and meditative undertakings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis and Shawn Hubler
title: Some Colleges Plan to Bring Back More Students in the Spring
description: College officials say they have learned important lessons about managing the pandemic on their campuses. Not everyone is so confident.
content: It was a tough fall semester for many American colleges and universities, with declining enrollment, canceled classes and sporting events, widespread Zoom fatigue and enough coronavirus-infected students nationwide to fill three and a half Rose Bowls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Pamela Tiffin, Movie Star Who Shone Brightly but Briefly, Dies at 78
description: Billy Wilder called her “the greatest film discovery since Audrey Hepburn,” and she made an immediate splash in two 1961 movies, when she was only 19.
content: Pamela Tiffin, the bouffant-haired brunette model turned actress who leapt to movie stardom at 19 in a Tennessee Williams drama and a Billy Wilder comedy, then ran away to make Italian movies and retired from acting before her 32nd birthday, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Manhattan. She was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: Winter Storm Blankets New England
description: Heavy snow and high winds created dangerous road conditions and left more than 250,000 customers without power in New England. The storm is expected to wind down in the region by Sunday evening.
content: Heavy snow and high winds created dangerous road conditions and left more than 250,000 customers without power in New England. The storm is expected to wind down in the region by Sunday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Social Life of Forests’
description: Trees appear to communicate and cooperate through subterranean networks of fungi. What are they sharing with one another?
content: Foresters once regarded trees as solitary individuals: They competed for space and resources, but were otherwise indifferent to one another.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Moment to Rethink U.S.-Saudi Ties
description: A reader suggests that President-elect Joe Biden should take a cleareyed look at what the kingdom is, and is not. Also: A pandemic haircut.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should Congress Bring Back Earmarks?
description: Readers discuss an editorial that argued that a revival of pork could help polarized lawmakers embrace negotiation and compromise.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 6, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Dec. 6, 2020.
content: Because of a transcription error, an article last Sunday about cannabis farms facing a devastating wildfire season misidentified the location of Sweet Creek Farm. It is in Guerneville, Calif., not Greenville.
source.name: The New York Times
